page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY - STRANRAER
page.content: Stranraer is the main town in the {Rhins of Galloway}- the central point for services,etc. The town developed from{Roman times} mainly through the influence of settlers, particulary from{Ireland.} The old town was situated between two burns and consisted of three parts - Hillhead, Clayhole and Stranraer. The three villages grew together to form the modern town of Stranraer. Stranraer received its Royal Burgh Charter in{1617}and has held its place of importance in the Rhins ever since. In more recent times the demise of the Portpatrick/Donaghadee ferry crossings led to the Stranraer/Larne route being established. Stranraer is now a busy ferry port serving mainland Britain and Ireland. The town has both grown in population and attracted industries as a result.
